ARTICLE.TITLE: SEC says IPO plans signal good faith
ARTICLE.TEXT:
SEC says IPO plans signal good faith

Investor sentiment has improved after the government eased lockdown measures, with IPO filings to list on the Thai bourse remaining at a normal proportion, says the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).

The securities watchdog reported its findings to recently appointed Finance Minister Predee Daochai after a meeting yesterday at the Bank of Thailand.

Apart from improved investor sentiment, IPO filings to list on the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) suggest signs of strong confidence because decisions to launch IPOs remain unchanged, said Ruenvadee Suwanmongkol, SEC's secretary-general.

The number of IPO filings is expected to reach 30-35 this year, considered typical, Ms Ruenvadee said.

More than 30 securities have submitted IPO filings to the SEC, but most have yet to specify an IPO period and first trading day.

There have been five IPOs this year, with two listing on the SET and three on the Market for Alternative Investment.

Combined market capitalisation at the IPO price was 303.9 billion baht as of Thursday.

The SEC chief's comments on improved investor sentiment contrasted with results from a recent survey of the Federation of Thai Capital Market Organisations (Fetco).

The investor confidence index for the three months to October fell 16% to 85.3 from June's 101.2, according to the monthly poll by Fetco.

An index below 80 points is considered bearish, 80-119 is neutral and over 119 is bullish.

Negative factors lowering investor confidence include the domestic political situation and the economic slowdown, as well as SET-listed companies' lower earnings, said Paiboon Nalinthrangkurn, Fetco's chairman.

Ms Ruenvadee said the SEC will adjust its strategy for this year to align with operations in the post-pandemic period.

The capital market regulator acknowledges some difficulty in meeting its targets amid the outbreak, so plans will have to be revised in accordance with a changing economic landscape and innovative technologies.

The SEC is still committed to digitising the Thai capital market, such as by providing a greater opportunity for local firms to raise capital through crowdfunding and by setting up a trading board for small and medium-sized enterprises, Ms Ruenvadee said.

"We need to help build up confidence for the growth of the economy and move the country forward," she said.

METADATA.description: Investor sentiment has improved after the government eased lockdown measures, with IPO filings to list on the Thai bourse remaining at a normal proportion, says the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).
METADATA.author: Bangkok Post Public Company Limited
